title-group.article-title: Racial discrimination and health-promoting vs damaging behaviors among African-American adults

author-notes.corresp: Irma Corral, PhD, Department of Psychiatric Medicine, Brody School of Medicine at ECU, 600 Moye Blvd, Mail Stop 694, Greenville, NC 27834, USA. Email: corrali@ecu.edu

abstract.p: Studies have found relationships between racial discrimination and increased health-damaging behaviors among African-Americans, but have not examined possible concomitant decreased health-promoting behaviors. We explored the role of discrimination in two health-promoting behaviors, consuming ≥ 5 fruits/vegetables daily (FVC) and physical activity (PA), for the first time, and likewise examined discrimination’s contribution to cigarette smoking, among a sample of N = 2118 African-American adults. Results revealed that discrimination contributed positively to smoking and to PA but was unrelated to FVC. These findings suggest that both adaptive and maladaptive health behaviors might be used to cope with the stress of discrimination.

body.p: There is abundant evidence of widespread, racial discrimination against Blacks/African-Americans in the United States, with these discriminatory (or racist) events ranging from being called racist names and charged more for goods and services, to housing and salary discrimination, to physical attacks (e.g. Borrell et al., 2007; Krieger, 2000; Landrine et al., 2006; Williams and Mohammed, 2009; Williams et al., 2003). Across a plethora of studies, 70–90% of African-Americans report experiencing at least one racist event in the past year, and 90–100% report experiencing at least one such event in their lifetimes (Bennett et al., 2005; Krieger, 2000; Landrine et al., 2006). Objective, non-self-report (e.g. housing, employment, and laboratory-experimental) data reveal that these reports of perceived discrimination significantly underestimate its actual frequency (Darity, 2003; Feagin, 2006; US Department of Housing and Urban Development, 2002). In part this is because African-Americans often do not categorize discrimination as such; other attributions – for example, the offending person is in a bad mood – are more likely than attributions to racial discrimination. Likewise and alternatively, events perceived and categorized as discrimination often are not reported because of fear of negative consequences such as being fired (for reviews, see Krieger, 2000; Mays et al., 2007; Williams and Mohamed, 2009).

The ubiquity of racial discrimination has spawned a body of theory and research on its potential role as a social determinant of poor health and health disparities among Blacks (Brondolo et al., 2011; Clark et al., 1999; Contrada et al., 2001; Landrine et al., 2006; Mays et al., 2007; Williams et al., 2003). In this research, discrimination is conceptualized as a chronic stressor that contributes to poor health in the same manner that other stressful events do, namely, by increasing biologic stress-responses (e.g. blood pressure and production of pro-inflammatory factors) and by similarly increasing health-damaging behaviors (these understood as maladaptive/poor strategies for coping with the stress of discrimination). Thus, studies of the role of discrimination in African-American health behavior have focused on its association with increases in health-damaging behaviors such as smoking and substance use (e.g. Bennett et al., 2005; Gibbons et al., 2004), and almost none have explored its role in possible concomitant decreases in health-promoting behaviors – for example decreased physical activity, fruit/vegetable consumption, and cancer screening (Dailey et al., 2007; Paradies, 2006; Shariff-Marco et al., 2010). Indeed, only one study examined the role of discrimination in mild physical activity (and found no relationship; Shariff-Marco et al., 2010) and none have examined its possible role in fruit/vegetable consumption (FVC) among African-Americans. Research on general stress, however, has found that stressful events contribute to increases in health-damaging behaviors (e.g. smoking) and contribute to decreases in some health-promoting/self-care behaviors (e.g. sufficient hours of sleep) as well (Taylor, 2011; Thiots, 2010); the latter suggests that discrimination (racist stress) might play a similar role in health-promoting behaviors among African-Americans.

Thus, this study explored the role of self-reported racial discrimination in two health-promoting behaviors for the first time, consuming ≥ 5 servings of fruits/vegetables per day (5+ FVC) and vigorous physical activity (PA), and examined the association between discrimination and cigarette smoking as well. Based on ample prior evidence, we expected a strong, positive association between discrimination and cigarette smoking (e.g. Bennett et al., 2005; Gibbons et al., 2004; Landrine et al., 2006); given the absence of evidence, no hypotheses were formed about the relationship between discrimination and the two health-promoting behaviors.

sec.title: Participants
sec.p: Participants were a random, statewide sample of N = 2190 California, Black adults, 1254 women (57.3%) and 936 (42.7%) men, whose ages ranged from 18 to 95 years (Mean = 43.8). Those not born in the USA (n = 72) were excluded, and analyses were based on the remaining N = 2118.

sec.title: Procedure
sec.p: Participants were sampled door-to-door, on weekends, by Black-adult surveyors, in randomly selected census tracts in seven California counties, and asked to complete a brief, anonymous, written health survey for $10 cash. The survey had an eighth-grade reading level and took 15 minutes to complete. Survey completion rates ranged from 85–100% depending on census tract and county. The study had the approval of the Institutional Review Board of San Diego State University.

sec.title: Measures/variables
sec.p: Perceived, recent racial/ethnic discrimination was assessed by a single item that has been used in prior studies, ‘How much racism or discrimination have you personally experienced in the past year?’ (Dailey et al., 2007; Shariff-Marco et al., 2010). Response categories ‘None’ and ‘A Little’ were summed together as Low, and categories ‘Somewhat’ and ‘A Lot’ were summed together as High. Standard, detailed questions on FVC were asked (i.e. weekly consumption of juice, fruit, salad, beans, etc.) and a 5 + Daily FVC variable calculated as in prior studies (Centers for Disease Control, 2006). Current Cigarette Smoking (Do you currently smoke cigarettes, even once in a while? YES/NO), and vigorous Physical Activity (PA) in the past month (Did you engage in any vigorous physical activity – one that made you sweat, or made your heart race – in the past 30 days? YES/NO) were assessed using standard items (Centers for Disease Control, 2006).

sec.title: Data-analytic strategy
sec.p: Chi-square analyses were used to describe and explore the data. Then, three hierarchical, logistic regressions were conducted (one for each outcome), with demographic variables (gender, age, income, education) entered on the first step, and Discrimination on the second.

sec.title: Descriptive/univariate analyses
sec.p:
Descriptive analyses revealed that the percentage of the sample who consumed the National Institutes of Health recommended five or more servings of fruits/vegetables daily was extremely low (YES 5+ FVC = 25.1% overall), and remained low (range 22.8% to 28.7% Yes 5+ FVC) irrespective of age, education, income, gender, and discrimination. Slight but significant differences by Age (Yes 5+FVC Mean Age = 41.75, No 5+ FVC Mean Age = 44.14, td.f. = 1876 = 2.799, p = .005) and Discrimination (Yes 5+ FVC for High Discrimination = 28.7% vs Low Discrimination = 22.8%,

sec.title: Multivariate analyses
sec.p: As shown in Table 1 and as predicted, discrimination was positively associated with smoking. The odds of current cigarette smoking were higher for men, lower for those with high education and high incomes, and 1.3 times higher for those reporting frequent (vs infrequent) discrimination. As shown in Table 2, racial discrimination was not associated with 5+ Daily FVC. FVC had no significant relationships with gender, education, income, or discrimination, and instead, only was associated (negatively) with age. As shown in Table 3, discrimination was associated with vigorous PA in the past month. The odds of any vigorous PA decreased with increasing age, were higher for men than women, were higher among those with high educations and higher incomes, and were 1.34 times higher among those reporting frequent/high (vs infrequent) discrimination in the past year.

caption.p: Hierarchical logistic regression predicting current smoking (Yes/No) from demographic variables and perceived recent racial discrimination

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: This study has three noteworthy results. First, it confirms the prior, well-established finding that racial discrimination – whether assessed with a single-item (Shariff-Marco et al., 2010) or a multidimensional scale (Landrine et al., 2006) – is positively associated with cigarette smoking among African-Americans; indeed, consistent with all prior studies, this study found that smoking was more common among Black men and among those with low education and incomes, as well as among those reporting frequent racial discrimination (e.g. Bennett et al., 2005; Gibbons et al; 2004; Landrine et al., 2006).

Second, in the first exploration of the relationship between racial discrimination and 5+FVC, we found no relationship; indeed, education and income also had no relationship to FVC. One possible explanation is that the level of 5+FVC was so low (25.1% overall) and the variance in (range of) FVC too restricted (22.8% to 28.7%) for relationships to be found with any predictor variable. Alternatively, this finding could mean that African-Americans’ well-known low levels of FVC and FVC disparities (Centers for Disease Control, 2006) might not be related to racial discrimination, but instead to other social and cultural variables. Foremost among such variables is residence in racially segregated, Black neighborhoods; 65% of African-Americans reside in such neighborhoods (Landrine and Corral, 2009) where access to fresh fruits/vegetables (Corral et al., 2011; Morland and Filomena, 2007) and associated FVC are both extremely low (Corral et al., 2011; Morland et al., 2002; Zenk et al., 2005).

Another possible explanation is that racist stress contributes to dietary behavior among Blacks (not by decreasing health-promoting diet but instead) by increasing health-damaging diet – that is, consumption of fast, fried, sugary, and high-fat foods in particular. Although consumption of such health-damaging foods is frequent among African-Americans and has clear negative health consequences (e.g. Bovell-Benjamin et al., 2010; Satia et al., 2004), no one has examined the possible contribution of racial discrimination to this dietary pattern (Shariff-Marco et al., 2010). Thus, studies examining the role of racial discrimination in both FVC and fast/sweet/fried food consumption among African-Americans are needed to test these speculative interpretations, and to clarify the relationship between racial discrimination and dietary behavior.

Finally, the third noteworthy finding was that racial discrimination was positively associated with vigorous PA. This result is not consistent with the sole other investigation that found no relationship between discrimination and PA (Shariff-Marco et al., 2010). The difference in findings no doubt reflects the use of mild PA (i.e. only walking was assessed) in the prior study versus any vigorous PA here. In any event, our novel finding is consistent with data indicating that African-Americans use a wide variety of adaptive (e.g. seeking social support) and maladaptive (e.g. smoking) strategies to cope with the stress of racial discrimination (Krieger, 2000). The unique finding that physical activity perhaps might be one adaptive strategy has important implications for interventions (e.g. where increasing PA can be added as a coping mechanism) and thus requires replication.

These findings, however, must be considered in the context of the limitations of this study. One obvious limitation is that we measured recent discrimination with single item instead of with a multidimensional scale. Although the single item used here is valid and reliable, and has been used more often than scales in research (Dailey et al., 2007; Landrine et al., 2006; Shariff-Marco et al., 2010), evidence indicates that stronger relationships between discrimination and some health behaviors are found when multidimensional discrimination scales are used (Landrine et al., 2006). Clearly, further studies of the role of racial discrimination in a variety of health behaviors among African-Americans (health-promoting behaviors in particular) are needed to elucidate the extent to which discrimination is a social determinant of health behavior and health–behavior disparities. Use of multidimensional scales in such studies would be particularly beneficial to ascertaining the nature of the discrimination–health behavior relationship among African-Americans.
